translated: Birth Stories
Ten-&-One Collection
The Chapter on the Four Gates
The Takka Birth Story
“There are no takka-fish, no āluvā-fish,
No biḷāli-fish, no kaḷambā-fish, dear:
All alone in the wilderness, in the middle of a charnel ground,
For what purpose, dear, do you dig a pit?”
“Your grandfather, dear, is very weak,
Afflicted with many illnesses and suffering;
I’ll bury him in a pit,

analyzed: na hi sa tam jīvitam rocayāmi
translated: I don’t approve of his life.”
“This evil thought has come to you,
You’re doing a cruel deed, you fool!
I’ll do the same to you, dear,
This kind of deed has been brought on by old age;
Following that old man, Kulla,
I’ll bury him in a pit, too.”

original: “Pharusāhi vācāhi pakubbamāno,🔽Āsajja maṁ tvaṁ vadase kumāra;🔽Putto mamaṁ orasako samāno,
analyzed: pharusāhi vācāhi pakubbamānaḥ  āsajja mam tvam vadase kumāra  puttaḥ mamam orasakaḥ samānaḥ
translated: “You’re speaking harshly, acting harshly,🔽You’re threatening me, young man;🔽Though I’m your father, you’re my son,

analyzed: ahita anukampī mama tu asi putta
translated: You’re a son who has compassion for his father.”

analyzed: na tā aham tāta ahita anukampī
translated: “I’m not without compassion for you, dear,

analyzed: hita anukampī te aham pi tāta
translated: I have compassion for you, dear;
But you’re doing an evil deed,

original: Arahāmi no vārayituṁ tato”.🔽“Yo mātaraṁ vā pitaraṁ saviṭṭha,
analyzed: arahāmi naḥ vārayitum tatas  yaḥ mātaram vā pitaram saviṭṭha
translated: I am not to be restrained.”🔽“He who harms his mother or father,
Or any other innocent person,
At the break-up of the body after death
Will undoubtedly go to hell.
He who cares for his mother and father
With food and drink,
At the break-up of the body after death
Will undoubtedly go to a good realm of existence.

analyzed: na me tvam putta ahita anukampī
translated: You are not compassionate to me, my son,

analyzed: hita anukampī me tu asi putta
translated: You are compassionate to my welfare, my son.
But I, though warned by my mother,
Still do this evil deed.”

analyzed: yā te sā bhariyā an ariya rūpā
translated: “That wife of yours who is so unwomanly,

analyzed: mātā mama isā sakiyā janā itti
translated: She is my mother, my own flesh and blood.
You have expelled her from the house,

analyzed: aññam pi te sā dukham āvaheyya
translated: And she will bring you misfortune.

analyzed: yā te sā bhariyā an ariya rūpā
translated: That wife of yours who is so unwomanly,

analyzed: mātā mama isā sakiyā janā itti
translated: She is my mother, my own flesh and blood.
She is like a tamed tusker, well-trained,
But that evil woman has returned.”
The Takkalajātaka is the eighth.
